prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2-18O transition at 391 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-H2-18O 4_{1,4}-3_{2,1} transition at 390.6078 GHz and the ortho-D2O 2_{1,1}-2_{0,2} transition at 403.5618 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 10 (for the representative window resolution) is required for the observation of the D2O line. The ortho-H2-18O should be detected with a SNR of more than 20. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The peak intensities of the ortho-H2-18O and ortho-D2O lines (see Table 1) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013) for H2-18O and Coutens et al. (2013) for D2O. We checked that the D2O line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2013). The D2O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 (for the representative window resolution) to be mapped. The H2-18O line will be then observed with more than 20 sigma. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, J?rgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency.

The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s.
A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations.

To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (size of ~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3".
The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Fundamental HDO transition at 464 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the HDO fundamental 1_{0,1}-0_{0,0} transition at 464.9245 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 40 (for the representative window resolution) is required to clearly map this line and detect line wings. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The peak intensity of the fundamental HDO line (see Table 1) is estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013) for HDO. We checked that the HDO line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012). The HDO line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 40 (for the representative window resolution) to be able to detect the line wings and study both the kinematics and the spatial distribution. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, J?rgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency.

The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s.
Two HD-18O line at 462.23 and 453.31 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations.

To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (size of ~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3".
The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2-18O transition at 489 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-H2-18O 4_{2,3}-3_{3,0} transition at 489.0543 GHz and the HDO 2_{0,2}-1_{1,1} transition at 490.5966 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 10 (for the representative window resolution) is required for the observation of the H2-18O line. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The peak intensities of the ortho-H2-18O and HDO lines (see Table 1) are estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Persson et al. (2013). We checked that the HDO line estimate is consistent with the RATRAN modeling done by Coutens et al. (2012). The H2-18O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 (for the representative window resolution) to be mapped. The HDO line will then also be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of about 10 as its line intensity is quite similar to the H2-18O line. The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, J?rgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency.

The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s.
An HD-18O line at 492.81 GHz will be targetted in the same setup for a tentative detection. A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations.

To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (size of ~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3".
The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Fundamental ortho-D2O transition at 607 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal has for aim to observe the ortho-D2O fundamental 1_{1,1}-0_{0,0} transition at 607.3496 GHz with a spatial resolution of 0.3 arcsec. A signal-to-noise ratio of 5 (for the representative window resolution) is required to detect the D2O line. Two different pointings are done to observe both the sources A and B.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The peak intensity of the fundamental ortho-D2O line (see Table 1) is estimated with an LTE approach using the previous results found by Coutens et al. (2013). We checked that the D2O line estimate is also consistent with the RATRAN modeling. The fundamental para-D2O line will be observed with a signal-to-noise ratio of 5 (for the representative window resolution) for a detection and a determination of the D2O/H2O ratio at least at the position of the peak emission. The D2O line intensity could however be brighter and detected with 8 sigma, considering the upper limit of the abundance determined by Coutens et al. (2013). The peak continuum flux density per beam is based on previous interferometric measurements towards this source (Chandler et al. 2005, J?rgensen et al. 2012, Pineda et al. 2012, Zapata et al. 2013, etc) with interpolation at the requested frequency.

The line widths are approximately about 5 km/s in the source A and 1 km/s in the source B. To spectrally resolve the line profiles, we consequently need a spectral resolution of about 0.1-0.2 km/s.
A very wide spectral window is added for continuum observations.

To be able to see variations of the water D/H ratio in the inner regions of IRAS16293A (size of ~ 1.5''), we need a spatial resolution of 0.3".
The two sources do not fit within the inner 1/3 of the primary beam. Two different pointings are then requested to observe the two sources A and B.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The evolution of water from its formation in the molecular cloud until its incorporation in the protoplanetary disk and then comets and asteroids is still unclear. Measuring the water D/H ratio is particularly helpful to answer this question. We propose to carry out multi-line observations of the water isotopologues (HDO, H2-18O and D2O) at high spatial resolution (0.3 arcsec, 35 AU diameter) towards the inner regions of the well-known Class 0 protobinary IRAS16293-2422, which is now possible thanks to the enhanced capabilities of ALMA. Through the study of the kinematics and the determination of the HDO/H2O and D2O/H2O ratios with radius from the protostars, we can determine if the water present at the Class 0 stage was preserved or reprocessed until its incorporation in disks and primitive icy bodies. The data will also allow us to determine the mechanisms that control the water vapor abundance in the warm inner regions of Class 0 protostars.
This proposal is a resubmission of the B-ranked Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00061.S.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Resubmission of the B-ranked Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00061.S: At the time of the Cycle 3 proposal deadline, the three first setups (see Table 1) have been observed, delivered and reduced. Any other data that pass QA2 before the start of Cycle 3 will not need to be re-observed and can be excluded from the Cycle 3 program.
